titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Delivered a letter from Mr: Töpfer of Waldenburg to Mr: Eichborn— He went with us to see the church of St: Elisabeth, and the Rhediger library— Mr: Scheibel the rector of the school, and librarian shew’d it us. The manuscript of Froissart is the principal curiosity it contains— Thence to the collection of paintings belonging to the Magdalen church; which were shewn us by the rector Mr: Manso.— After dinner We saw the Augustine church on the sand island; the cathedral on the dome island, with the bishop’s present residence and the palace he is building; after which we went to Scheidnich the seat and gardens of Prince Hohenlohe the governor of Breslau; who last week entertained the king and queen there with great splendour.

2. Went this forenoon to see the manufactures of turkish yarn, and of needles—likewise a workman who takes likenesses in stucco— Dined with Mr: Eichborn at the ressource, in a company of about forty persons. After dinner we went to see the Jesuits church, and the Leopoldine hall— Saw the observatory at the top of the building; Afterwards to the sugar-refinery, and the barracks— In the evening at the play, where we saw the Apothecary and the Doctor.

3. Went this morning to see the foundary of cannon; but they have not work’d at it these two years; and it is only for the account of the king.— In the afternoon we left Breslau, and came four miles to Neumarckt.

4. Came through Liegnitz, and Goldberg, eleven miles to Hirschberg, where we arrived at ten at night. Saw at Liegnitz the Jesuit’s church, the cloth-manufactory, and the academy of knights— At Goldberg, were at a cloth manufacturers— Came over the Capellenberg.
5. Took a day of rest. Called upon Mr: Hesse this afternoon, but he was not at home— In the evening, at the play— Saw the elopement; a comedy I had seen before at Berlin.

6. Mr: Hesse called upon us, and we took leave of him— Called at Mr: Schäffer’s; he was not at home— This evening between 6 and 7. o’clock we left Hirschberg and went five miles to Flinsberg. Rode till one in the morning.

7. Found no post station here, and were obliged to go on with the horses we took from Hirschberg. I could not go up either the grosse kamm, or the Tafelfichte— Went in the morning just to take a distant view at Mäffersdorf.— Came through Friedeberg to Greiffenberg the last Silesian town; and thence to Lauban the first town in Lusace—lodg’d at Görlitz where we arrived in the evening between 7. and 8. Came this day 7 miles.

8. Took a chaise and went with Whitcomb, three miles to Herrnhuth, the primitive settlement of the Moravian brotherhood— The roads were so bad that Mrs: A. could not go.— Tis the first of the Moravian communities I have seen. Went over the young men’s and young women’s house— The church and burying ground; the great store; the apothecary’s shop, and several private tradesmen’s shops— Count Zinzendorf the founder of the institution is buried here. His daughter, and her husband, a Baron de Watteville still reside here; and at Bertelsdorf a village, near at hand;— We returned to Görlitz about 9 o’clock in the evening.

9. Look’d at some damask table linen, in a store: this is the part of Saxony where it is principally made. Left Görlitz, and came through Rothkretscham six miles to Bauzen— Rainy afternoon; and I got wet through. Miss’d the opportunity of going up the Landeskrone at Görlitz.

10. Left Bauzen at 8 this morning, and came seven miles through Schmiedefeld to Dresden, where we arrived at four in the afternoon. Lodge at the Hotel de Pologne; up three pair of stairs— Endeavoured without success to get other lodgings.— Found Mr: Cohen’s family here; and he is extremely ill— Has had a putrid fever— Walked out of the black gate, towards evening.

11. Whitcomb went off this morning to Leipzig, at 5 o’clock— Went this forenoon to the picture-gallery, and was charmed with another sight of my old acquaintance there— Met the Miss Blumenthal’s and the Commandeur d’Araujo; who has given up his plan of a tour into Silesia— Called upon Mr: Cohen.— Spent the afternoon and evening at our lodgings.— A rainy day.

12. Visited this forenoon Mr: Elliot and Count Zinzendorf, neither of whom I found at home— Lord Holland I saw and the Commandeur d’Araujo— Went with him and Mr: and Madame Cappadoce to see the Panorama of the city of London— The same I saw in London.— Called in the afternoon upon Mr: Gray, who was not at home. Went to the play with Mrs: A— It is out of the town— We went down from the bridge by water; and walk’d back.— The play was the elopement from the Seraglio.

13. Went this forenoon with Mrs: A. to see the elector’s collection of prints which is one of the finest in Europe— They are kept in one of the rooms of the Zwinger, which is hung round with drawings copied from pictures in the gallery.— We spent three hours here, in which time we could only look over four or five out of some thousands of volumes— The collection of Nanteuil’s works, a french engraver in Louis 14th: reign. That of Bause a german artist, yet living, a volume of Guercino’s designs and sketches engraved by Bartolozzi, and a series of prints from the first periods of the art to that of its present perfection, amused us this forenoon; and we propose to return another day, to see further— After dinner we went through the Plauenschen grund to Tharandt, which has often been extoll’d to us as a ride, of extraordinary beauty; but it loses much to a traveller coming from Silesia— It is more than a two hours ride there— We return’d between 8 and 9 in the evening.

14. Went this forenoon to hear the mass at the great catholic church— Afterwards paid a visit to Prince and Princess Radziwill, who lodge in the house with us— Saw there the Prince’s mother and two sisters. Countess Werthern, Lord and Lady Holland, Mr: Elliot and Mrs: Rawdon, an english lady who travels with the princess. Mrs: A. spent the evening with Mrs: Cohen— I went to the play, and saw the red cap; a comic opera. The music of Dittersdorf, and very good.

15. Went again to the electoral prints and spent the forenoon in looking over a collection of portraits engraved by Bartolozzi, from designs of Holbein— They are all of distinguished english characters during the reigns of Henry 8th: and of his children— They are published by Mr: Chamberlaine— We likewise look’d over a volume of engravings from Raphael, consisting in a great measure of grotesques and arabesques from his fresco paintings. There are ten volumes of his works— The collection of prints from the pictures in the gallery here, is very incomplete, and in general poorly executed.— I took only three of the prints— In the afternoon I pass’d a couple of hours with Mrs: A. in the gallery. Afterwards I paid a visit to Mr: Elliot— Found him confined with an head ache— Mrs: Elliot went out— Had a long conversation with him— In the course of it he took occasion to speak of the robbery of Arthur Lee’s paper’s during the American war, which has always been imputed to him— He declared solemnly that he did not order it: that it was entirely the work of a servant, though when the papers were brought to him he did read them.
That the only papers of consequence he found, were the draught, of an unfinish’d Treaty with Spain; and a letter from Frederic the second or one of his ministers, promising, if any other power would set the example of acknowledging the independence of the United States, that he would be the second to do it.— He was very much offended at this transaction, and Mr: Elliot was obliged to send the man who had committed the robbery, privately out of the country.

16. Pass’d the forenoon at the gallery of pictures, of which I have now taken leave, probably forever— At three this afternoon we left Dresden, and came three miles to Meissen, through a country which seems to be a continual vineyard— At this place is the great Saxon porcelain manufactory which we have not time to see.

17. Between 6 and 7 in the morning we left Meissen, and came 9 1/2 miles to Leipzig, which we reached, at about ten at night— We dined at Wärmsdorf, a village in which stands the castle of Hubertsburg; famous as the place where the peace which terminated the seven year’s war, was sign’d— About a mile before reaching Leipzig, we found Whitcomb who had come out so far to meet us— We came immediately to the lodgings he has taken for us.

18. Walk’d about the town, both in the forenoon and afternoon— Went in the evening with Mrs: Adams to the university church, where we heard perform’d Haydn’s Creation, a celebrated musical work, which did not answer my expectation— The music is certainly fine, but perhaps it is impossible to do justice to such a subject. The words are partly taken from the bible; partly from Milton’s hymn of Adam and Eve, and partly put together by a Gentleman at Vienna. They would have been better if the airs had been rhym’d.

19. Mrs: A. took a bad cold yesterday at the concert and is this day quite unwell.— Subscribed at Beygang’s circulating library. Took this afternoon a walk round the town— It is remarkably agreeable; a hard terrass with rows of trees which form a pleasant shade— Read this evening part of the second volume of the Canterbury tales— The young Lady’s tale, by Miss Sophia Lee.

20. Delivered a letter this morning from Mr: Frege Schickler to Mr: Frege, a merchant and banker here of the first consideration and property. He expects his nephew daily home from Philadelphia, where he has spent a couple of years.— In the afternoon I went to Beygang’s circulating library, and museum, where are all the newspapers and journals.— Reading Mad: de Genlis’s Adele et Theodore. Mrs: A— very ill indeed, this afternoon— We have a dismal month before us.

21. Mrs: A— somewhat better, but could not go out— I went to dine with Mr: Frege, at his country seat, about a german mile out of town— He has a very fine house and gardens— The company consisted of about twenty persons, all strangers to me— Return’d just at dark, and read, in the evening to Mrs: A.
22. I have almost entirely left off writing and spend all my time in reading. Call’d this afternoon at the circulating library, and walk’d round the town— Read in the evening to Mrs: A.

23. Unwell with a severe cough and pain in my breast, which obliges me to cease reading loud, altogether— Went this evening to the play and saw Kotzebue’s Octavia, a tragedy which I found better than I had expected. The character of Cleopatra is too infamous, and that of Octavia too exalted for human-nature— Antony is too favourably exhibited likewise— The house is a very good one; but the company is indifferent— They act no musical pieces.

24. Finish’d reading the second volume of the Canterbury tales, and likewise Madame de Genlis’s Adele et Theodore. Being in a great measure disabled to write, I read the more rapidly. There are many good ideas upon education in Adele et Theodore; but in general too great a degree of docility is supposed in the children; and too much of stratagem or intrigue is recommended in the management of them— Walk round the town this afternoon.

25. Read the first volume of Lewis’s Monk; a book of which I have heard much, but which I had never read. It is a new edition, and the greatest indelicacies which had been complained of in the first are expunged from it— Went this evening to the play, and was amused with the Sorceress in the wood, or the dumb knight, by Kotzebue.
26. Confined myself to the house, owing to the cough and pain in my breast.— Read a little, and wrote a little— Letter from Mr: Welsh— Weather cold and rainy.

27. Still confined with my complaint, for which I consulted at length Dr Kapp, a physician recommended to me by Mr: Frege.— Consulted him likewise with respect to Mrs: A— but her case no physician can remedy. First fire this evening— Finish’d Lewis’s Monk.

28. Confined to the house all this day likewise— Cold and rainy almost the whole day. Visit from the Doctor, this morning, and again in the afternoon— He prescribed for Mrs: A— T’is to no purpose— Reading Miss Burney’s Camilla.

29. Michaelmas day— From which the fair, commences— The weather being fine, and as I find myself better, I took a short walk about the town in the forenoon, and in the afternoon called at the circulating library— The rest of the day at home— Mrs: A.’s illness rapidly approaching.— She is already very unwell, and will continue so untill the severe and inevitable trial has had its usual end.
30. From four in the morning, every street is full of bustle, buyers, sellers and goods. The weather so bad I could not go out the whole day— The doctor here this afternoon— My cough getting better.

Day. Since taking our lodgings here I rise usually before six; read till nine; breakfast— Read or write a little and dress— Dine at one— Read again untill dark— Play cards with Mrs: A— till 9. Sup, and go to bed at ten— Before I was obliged to confine myself to the house, I walk’d usually an hour before and as much after dinner.— My illness and that of Mrs: A. make me irresistibly lazy.
